title: 2 Kings Chapter 3 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on 2 Kings chapter 3 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: 2 Kings Chapter 3 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of 2 Kings Chapter 3.

questions.question: Who began to reign over Israel in Samaria in the eighteenth year of Jehoshaphat king of Judah?
options: Jehoram
Ahab
Mesha
Jeroboam
questions.correctAnswer: Jehoram
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 3:1 states that Jehoram the son of Ahab began to reign over Israel in Samaria in the eighteenth year of Jehoshaphat king of Judah.

questions.question: What evil did Jehoram do compared to his parents?
options: He did evil but put away the image of Baal his father had made
He built more images of Baal
He worshipped only the LORD
He made peace with Moab
questions.correctAnswer: He did evil but put away the image of Baal his father had made
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 3:2 explains Jehoram wrought evil in the sight of the LORD but unlike his parents, he removed the image of Baal his father had made.

questions.question: What sin did Jehoram continue to follow according to 2 Kings 3?
options: The sins of Jeroboam son of Nebat
Idolatry of Baal
Worship of the Moabite gods
Building altars to the LORD
questions.correctAnswer: The sins of Jeroboam son of Nebat
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 3:3 states that Jehoram cleaved unto the sins of Jeroboam son of Nebat which made Israel sin.

questions.question: What tribute did Mesha king of Moab render to the king of Israel?
options: One hundred thousand lambs and rams with wool
Gold and silver
Grain and wine
Forty camels
questions.correctAnswer: One hundred thousand lambs and rams with wool
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 3:4 says Mesha king of Moab was a sheepmaster and gave the king of Israel one hundred thousand lambs and one hundred thousand rams with wool.

questions.question: True or False: After Ahab's death, the king of Moab remained loyal to Israel.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 3:5 states that after Ahab was dead, the king of Moab rebelled against the king of Israel.

questions.question: Who did king Jehoram ask to join him in battle against Moab?
options: Jehoshaphat king of Judah
Elisha the prophet
The king of Edom
Jeroboam
questions.correctAnswer: Jehoshaphat king of Judah
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 3:7 records that Jehoram sent to Jehoshaphat king of Judah to join him against Moab in battle.

questions.question: Through which wilderness did the kings decide to go up to Moab?
options: The wilderness of Edom
The wilderness of Sinai
The wilderness of Judah
The wilderness of Jericho
questions.correctAnswer: The wilderness of Edom
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 3:8 states that the way to go up was through the wilderness of Edom.

questions.question: True or False: The kings and their armies found abundant water during their seven days' journey.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 3:9 says there was no water for the host or cattle during their seven days' journey.

questions.question: Who did Jehoshaphat suggest they inquire of to seek the LORD's guidance?
options: A prophet of the LORD
The king of Edom
The priests of Moab
The commanders of Israel
questions.correctAnswer: A prophet of the LORD
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 3:11 states Jehoshaphat asked if there was a prophet of the LORD to inquire of Him.

questions.question: Who was the prophet they went to for counsel?
options: Elisha son of Shaphat
Elijah
Jeremiah
Isaiah
questions.correctAnswer: Elisha son of Shaphat
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 3:11 identifies Elisha son of Shaphat as the prophet they sought.

questions.question: What was Elisha's initial reaction to the king of Israel's request?
options: He questioned why he should help him
He immediately agreed
He gave a prophecy of victory
He asked for a sacrifice
questions.correctAnswer: He questioned why he should help him
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 3:13 shows Elisha saying, 'What have I to do with thee?' and telling the king to go to the prophets of his parents.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Elisha said, 'As the LORD of hosts liveth, before whom I stand, surely, were it not that I regard the presence of ________, I would not look toward thee, nor see thee.'
options: Jehoshaphat the king of Judah
Mesha the king of Moab
Ahab king of Israel
Elijah the prophet
questions.correctAnswer: Jehoshaphat the king of Judah
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 3:14 reveals Elisha respected Jehoshaphat's presence, which is why he helped.

questions.question: What did Elisha instruct the kings to make the valley full of?
options: Ditches
Trees
Altars
Walls
questions.correctAnswer: Ditches
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 3:16 records Elisha's command to make the valley full of ditches.

questions.question: True or False: The valley was filled with water without wind or rain as a sign from the LORD.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 3:17 confirms the valley was filled with water though there was no wind or rain.

questions.question: What did the Moabites see that made them think the kings were slain?
options: Water as red as blood
Smoke from the campfire
Dust clouds from battle
The kings’ banners lowered
questions.correctAnswer: Water as red as blood
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 3:22 reports the Moabites saw the water as red as blood and thought the kings had killed each other.

medium.title: 2 Kings Chapter 3 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from 2 Kings Chapter 3 to real-life situations.

questions.question: How does 2 Kings 3 teach us about trusting God when facing seemingly impossible situations?
options: Trust God and seek His guidance through His prophets
Rely only on our own military strength
Ignore the problem and hope it resolves itself
Make alliances without consulting God
questions.correctAnswer: Trust God and seek His guidance through His prophets
questions.explanation: Jehoshaphat asked if there was a prophet of the LORD to inquire of Him (2 Kings 3:11-12). Elisha then gave God’s instructions, showing the importance of seeking God's guidance in difficult trials (2 Kings 3:15-19).

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling to maintain faith when plans seem to fail. Based on Jehoram’s experience in 2 Kings 3, what biblical truth would you share?
options: God can provide unexpectedly, even without rain or wind
Success depends only on human effort
Doubt is justified when things look bleak
Faith is irrelevant in times of conflict
questions.correctAnswer: God can provide unexpectedly, even without rain or wind
questions.explanation: Elisha assured them that though they would not see wind or rain, the valley would be filled with water (2 Kings 3:17-20), teaching faith in God’s provision despite difficult circumstances.

questions.question: What example from 2 Kings 3 shows the importance of humility before God?
options: Elisha refusing to help Jehoram except for Jehoshaphat’s sake
Jehoram trusting his own armies without seeking God
Mesha rebelling against Israel without repentance
The kings celebrating their alliance prematurely
questions.correctAnswer: Elisha refusing to help Jehoram except for Jehoshaphat’s sake
questions.explanation: Elisha said he would not look toward Jehoram but for Jehoshaphat’s presence he would help (2 Kings 3:13-14), showing God honors humility and sincere seeking.

questions.question: How does this passage demonstrate the value of cooperation and unity in church or fellowship life?
options: Three kings joined forces to face a common enemy
Each king acted independently to protect his kingdom
They avoided alliances to prevent conflict
They competed for control over Moab
questions.correctAnswer: Three kings joined forces to face a common enemy
questions.explanation: The kings of Israel, Judah, and Edom combined their forces to battle Moab (2 Kings 3:7-9), illustrating the power of unity and cooperation among God’s people.

questions.question: Based on 2 Kings 3, what practical lesson can parents learn about modeling faith for their children?
options: Like Jehoram, children may follow the sins of their predecessors despite some reforms
Faith is only important for rulers, not families
Parents’ actions do not influence their children’s spiritual choices
Children should rebel against their parents’ faith
questions.correctAnswer: Like Jehoram, children may follow the sins of their predecessors despite some reforms
questions.explanation: Jehoram put away Baal’s image but still clung to Jeroboam’s sins (2 Kings 3:2-3), showing the complexity of spiritual inheritance and the need for intentional faith modeling.

questions.question: What does the Moabite king’s extreme action in 2 Kings 3:27 teach about desperation and losing trust in God?
options: Desperation can lead to ungodly choices that bring God's indignation
Sacrificing others earns God’s favor
God accepts any form of worship during crisis
Human strength alone can overcome defeat
questions.correctAnswer: Desperation can lead to ungodly choices that bring God's indignation
questions.explanation: Mesha offered his son as a burnt offering, provoking God's indignation and ending the battle (2 Kings 3:27), showing the danger of turning from God in desperation.

questions.question: True or False: Jehoram completely abandoned all the sins of his father and mother during his reign.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Jehoram put away the image of Baal but still cleaved to the sins of Jeroboam, not fully abandoning his parents' sinful ways (2 Kings 3:2-3).

questions.question: True or False: The kings found water for their armies and cattle only after they obeyed Elisha’s instructions and made the valley full of ditches.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Elisha instructed them to make ditches and God provided water without wind or rain, filling the valley (2 Kings 3:16-20).

questions.question: How does Elisha’s response to Jehoram in 2 Kings 3:13-14 teach us about honoring those who seek God sincerely?
options: God honors those who sincerely seek Him, even if others do not
God ignores all requests from sinful leaders
God helps only those from Judah
God’s help is based on political alliances
questions.correctAnswer: God honors those who sincerely seek Him, even if others do not
questions.explanation: Elisha was willing to help because of Jehoshaphat’s presence and faith, showing God’s favor toward sincere seekers (2 Kings 3:14-15).

questions.question: A believer is tempted to rely on their own understanding in difficult times. Based on 2 Kings 3, what biblical principle about obedience would you share?
options: Obedience to God's word, even when it seems unusual, brings provision and victory
Ignoring God leads to better results
Success depends on human wisdom alone
Waiting without action is the best course
questions.correctAnswer: Obedience to God's word, even when it seems unusual, brings provision and victory
questions.explanation: The kings obeyed Elisha’s instruction to dig ditches, resulting in water and victory (2 Kings 3:16-20), teaching the blessing of faithful obedience.

questions.question: What does the campaign against Moab in 2 Kings 3 teach about stewardship and integrity in leadership?
options: Leaders must act justly by following God's commands and not abusing power
Leaders should use deception to win at all costs
Military success justifies any action
Ignoring God's instructions is acceptable if victorious
questions.correctAnswer: Leaders must act justly by following God's commands and not abusing power
questions.explanation: Elisha commanded them to destroy cities, trees, and wells (2 Kings 3:19, 25), showing that even in warfare there is a call to execute God’s justice, not personal gain.

questions.question: How does the alliance of Israel, Judah, and Edom in 2 Kings 3 challenge believers about fellowship and serving others?
options: True fellowship involves cooperation and mutual support for God’s purposes
Fellowship is only for those of the same background
Each believer should work alone to avoid conflict
Serving others is optional in hard times
questions.correctAnswer: True fellowship involves cooperation and mutual support for God’s purposes
questions.explanation: The three kings joined together, showing the power of unity in fulfilling God’s will (2 Kings 3:7-9).

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Elisha instructed the kings to make the valley full of ________, so it would be filled with water even without rain.
options: ditches
wells
fences
altars
questions.correctAnswer: ditches
questions.explanation: Elisha said, 'Make this valley full of ditches' so water would appear miraculously (2 Kings 3:16-17).

questions.question: What spiritual lesson about perseverance can be drawn from the kings’ seven-day journey through the wilderness without water in 2 Kings 3?
options: Faith perseveres through dry, challenging seasons trusting God’s provision
Giving up when resources run out is wise
Human planning is more reliable than God’s promises
Avoid hard paths to ensure safety
questions.correctAnswer: Faith perseveres through dry, challenging seasons trusting God’s provision
questions.explanation: The kings faced a lack of water but continued trusting God’s prophet, demonstrating perseverance in faith (2 Kings 3:9-11).

questions.question: How does the response of the Moabites to the water looking like blood in 2 Kings 3 teach about the power of perception and faith in spiritual battles?
options: False appearances can cause fear and defeat without real conflict
Perception does not affect battle outcomes
Only physical strength wins battles
Faith is unnecessary in warfare
questions.correctAnswer: False appearances can cause fear and defeat without real conflict
questions.explanation: The Moabites thought the water was blood and assumed the kings were dead, leading to their defeat (2 Kings 3:22-24), showing how faith and perception affect outcomes.

hard.title: 2 Kings Chapter 3 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from 2 Kings Chapter 3.

questions.question: What significant act differentiates Jehoram's reign from that of his parents according to 2 Kings 3?
options: He put away the image of Baal that his father had made
He built altars to Baal in Samaria
He formed an alliance with Moab
He destroyed the temple of the LORD
questions.correctAnswer: He put away the image of Baal that his father had made
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 3:2 states that Jehoram 'put away the image of Baal that his father had made,' which distinguishes his reign from that of his father and mother.

questions.question: Which sin did Jehoram persist in despite removing Baal's image?
options: The sins of Jeroboam son of Nebat
Worship of Asherah poles
Child sacrifice
Idolatry of Moloch
questions.correctAnswer: The sins of Jeroboam son of Nebat
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 3:3 explicitly states Jehoram 'cleaved unto the sins of Jeroboam the son of Nebat,' which led Israel to sin.

questions.question: What was the annual tribute Mesha king of Moab rendered to Israel before rebelling?
options: 100,000 lambs and 100,000 rams with the wool
50,000 camels
10,000 talents of silver
A yearly supply of grain and wine
questions.correctAnswer: 100,000 lambs and 100,000 rams with the wool
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 3:4 describes Mesha as a sheepmaster who rendered 'an hundred thousand lambs, and an hundred thousand rams, with the wool' to Israel yearly.

questions.question: Which route did the kings take to fight against Moab, and what was its significant geographical challenge?
options: Through the wilderness of Edom, which lacked water
Along the coastal plain of the Mediterranean Sea
Through the fertile land of Gilead
Across the Jordan River valley
questions.correctAnswer: Through the wilderness of Edom, which lacked water
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 3:8-9 says they went through the wilderness of Edom and faced a seven-day journey with no water for people or cattle.

questions.question: How did Jehoshaphat respond to the crisis of no water during the journey to Moab?
options: He asked if there was a prophet of the LORD to inquire of Him
He commanded the army to turn back
He sent spies to find water
He prayed alone without consulting anyone
questions.correctAnswer: He asked if there was a prophet of the LORD to inquire of Him
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 3:11 records Jehoshaphat asking if there was a prophet of the LORD to consult during their distress.

questions.question: Who was the prophet consulted by the kings, and what was his connection to Elijah?
options: Elisha, son of Shaphat, who poured water on Elijah's hands
Micaiah, the son of Imlah, Elijah's disciple
Elijah himself, resurrected
Samuel, appearing through a vision
questions.correctAnswer: Elisha, son of Shaphat, who poured water on Elijah's hands
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 3:11-12 identifies Elisha as the prophet who poured water on Elijah’s hands, indicating his prophetic succession.

questions.question: What literary device is evident in Elisha's initial rebuke of the king of Israel and his ultimate assistance because of Jehoshaphat?
options: Chiasm emphasizing divine favor to Judah
Parallelism between Israel and Judah
Typology foreshadowing the Messiah
Alliteration highlighting prophetic authority
questions.correctAnswer: Chiasm emphasizing divine favor to Judah
questions.explanation: Elisha's words in 2 Kings 3:13-14 form a chiasm showing God's partiality to Jehoshaphat and reluctance toward Israel’s king due to his sins.

questions.question: What miraculous sign did Elisha instruct the kings to prepare, and what was its symbolic significance?
options: Fill the valley with ditches to be filled with water despite no rain, symbolizing God's provision
Build an altar on the mountain to invoke fire from heaven
Offer a burnt sacrifice to appease Moab
Plant trees to symbolize restoration
questions.correctAnswer: Fill the valley with ditches to be filled with water despite no rain, symbolizing God's provision
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 3:16-17 shows Elisha commanding the making of ditches that would be filled with water supernaturally, demonstrating God's power to provide.

questions.question: What military strategy against Moab was instructed by Elisha after the miraculous provision of water?
options: Smite every fenced city, fell every good tree, stop all wells, and mar the good land
Lay siege to the capital only
Offer peace treaties to Moabite leaders
Use psychological warfare by spreading rumors
questions.correctAnswer: Smite every fenced city, fell every good tree, stop all wells, and mar the good land
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 3:19 orders a scorched-earth policy to weaken Moab, indicating total warfare strategy.

questions.question: How did the Moabites misinterpret the water on their border, and what was the consequence?
options: They thought it was blood and assumed Israel's kings had slain each other, leading to overconfidence
They believed it was poison and avoided battle
They saw it as a flood and retreated
They thought it was holy water and surrendered
questions.correctAnswer: They thought it was blood and assumed Israel's kings had slain each other, leading to overconfidence
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 3:22-23 explains the Moabites saw water as red as blood, falsely believing the enemy kings were dead, prompting a reckless attack.

questions.question: What was the outcome of the battle after the Moabites misjudged the situation?
options: Israelites defeated Moabites, who fled and lost territory
Moabites captured the kings of Israel and Judah
The battle ended in a stalemate
The Moabites successfully repelled the invaders
questions.correctAnswer: Israelites defeated Moabites, who fled and lost territory
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 3:24 records Israel smiting the Moabites who fled, and Israel pursued them, taking the fight into Moab's country.

questions.question: What extreme act did the king of Moab commit when faced with defeat, and what was its immediate effect on the Israelites?
options: He sacrificed his eldest son as a burnt offering, causing great indignation against Israel
He fled to Edom to seek refuge
He called for a truce and surrendered
He poisoned the wells to halt the Israelites
questions.correctAnswer: He sacrificed his eldest son as a burnt offering, causing great indignation against Israel
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 3:27 recounts the king of Moab offering his son as a burnt offering, which provoked indignation and ended the conflict.

questions.question: True or False: According to 2 Kings 3, Jehoram king of Israel consulted the prophets of his father and mother before going to Elisha.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 3:13 shows Elisha rebuking Jehoram for not consulting the prophets of his father and mother, indicating Jehoram did not seek their counsel first.

questions.question: In the context of 2 Kings 3, how does the episode of Elisha's prophecy and the miraculous water supply foreshadow later biblical themes?
options: God's provision in barren places and themes of renewal and deliverance
The futility of human alliances without divine support
The condemnation of idolatry leading to exile
The final judgment by fire and flood
questions.correctAnswer: God's provision in barren places and themes of renewal and deliverance
questions.explanation: The miraculous filling of the valley despite no rain (2 Kings 3:16-17) foreshadows God's provision in wilderness and deliverance themes seen throughout Scripture, such as in Exodus and the New Testament.

questions.question: Which historical and cultural context is reflected in the Moabite rebellion and tribute described in 2 Kings 3?
options: Vassal states paying tribute to dominant Israelite kingdom and rebelling upon a power vacuum
Peaceful coexistence through mutual trade
Alliance through intermarriage between Moab and Israel
Moabite dominance over Israel
questions.correctAnswer: Vassal states paying tribute to dominant Israelite kingdom and rebelling upon a power vacuum
questions.explanation: 2 Kings 3:4-5 reflects the common ancient Near Eastern practice of vassal states like Moab paying tribute and rebelling when the overlord’s power weakened.

theological.title: 2 Kings Chapter 3 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from 2 Kings Chapter 3 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: What does 2 Kings 3 reveal about the nature of Jehoram's reign over Israel?
options: He did evil but removed the image of Baal.
He reigned righteously with full obedience to God.
He rebuilt the temple in Samaria.
He allied with Assyria against Judah.
questions.correctAnswer: He did evil but removed the image of Baal.
questions.explanation: Jehoram did evil in the sight of the LORD but unlike his parents, he removed the image of Baal (2 Kings 3:2). This shows partial repentance but continued sin (cf. Romans 3:23; 1 Kings 16:30-33; Revelation 2:20).

questions.question: According to 2 Kings 3, which sin did Jehoram continue to cleave to, showing persistent idolatry?
options: The sins of Jeroboam son of Nebat
Adultery and murder
Child sacrifice
Worship of Asherah poles
questions.correctAnswer: The sins of Jeroboam son of Nebat
questions.explanation: Jehoram did not depart from the sins of Jeroboam, who led Israel into idolatry (2 Kings 3:3). This indicates ongoing covenant unfaithfulness (cf. 1 Kings 12:26-33; Hosea 3:1; Amos 5:26).

questions.question: What was the initial tribute that Mesha king of Moab rendered to Israel before rebelling?
options: One hundred thousand lambs and one hundred thousand rams with wool
Silver and gold
Grain and wine
Thousands of warriors
questions.correctAnswer: One hundred thousand lambs and one hundred thousand rams with wool
questions.explanation: Mesha was a sheepmaster who paid a significant tribute of sheep and wool to Israel (2 Kings 3:4), symbolizing subjugation and economic dependence (cf. 2 Kings 1:2; Jeremiah 25:26; Ezekiel 25:8-11).

questions.question: What was the strategic alliance formed against Moab in 2 Kings 3?
options: The kings of Israel, Judah, and Edom united against Moab
Israel and Assyria formed an alliance
Judah and Egypt allied against Israel
Moab allied with Aram and Ammon
questions.correctAnswer: The kings of Israel, Judah, and Edom united against Moab
questions.explanation: The kings of Israel, Judah, and Edom joined forces to fight Moab (2 Kings 3:9), reflecting a coalition of God's people and neighbors against rebellion (cf. Psalm 2:1-4; Isaiah 8:9; Revelation 17:12-14).

questions.question: How did the coalition armies respond to the lack of water during their seven-day journey through the wilderness of Edom?
options: They feared they would be delivered into Moab’s hands
They stopped and returned home immediately
They dug wells to find water
They sent a messenger to request supplies
questions.correctAnswer: They feared they would be delivered into Moab’s hands
questions.explanation: The king of Israel lamented that the LORD had called the kings together only to deliver them to Moab (2 Kings 3:10), showing human fear amidst divine testing (cf. Exodus 17:1-7; Numbers 20:2-13; Psalm 46:1-3).

questions.question: Who was sought out as a prophet to inquire of the LORD, demonstrating reliance on divine guidance?
options: Elisha, son of Shaphat
Elijah the Tishbite
Micaiah son of Imlah
Nathan the prophet
questions.correctAnswer: Elisha, son of Shaphat
questions.explanation: Jehoshaphat insisted on consulting Elisha, who had the word of the LORD (2 Kings 3:11-12), emphasizing the necessity of prophetic revelation for guidance (cf. 1 Kings 19:16; Luke 1:76; Hebrews 1:1).

questions.question: What was Elisha’s initial response to the king of Israel, and what does it reveal about prophetic authority?
options: He rebuked him, saying, 'What have I to do with thee?'
He immediately blessed the king’s cause
He prophesied defeat for Israel
He refused to speak at all
questions.correctAnswer: He rebuked him, saying, 'What have I to do with thee?'
questions.explanation: Elisha initially distanced himself from Jehoram, showing prophetic independence and judgment on past apostasy (2 Kings 3:13), a reminder that true prophets represent God's word, not royal agendas (cf. Jeremiah 1:19; Amos 7:12-15; Acts 4:19).

questions.question: Why did Elisha agree to help the coalition against Moab, according to 2 Kings 3?
options: Because of the presence of Jehoshaphat king of Judah
Because Jehoram promised him riches
Because the Moabites repented
Because the LORD commanded him
questions.correctAnswer: Because of the presence of Jehoshaphat king of Judah
questions.explanation: Elisha stated he would honor Jehoshaphat's presence, indicating his respect for the godly king of Judah (2 Kings 3:14) and exemplifying how godly leadership influences God's mercy (cf. 2 Chronicles 20:6; Psalm 101:2-3; 1 Timothy 2:1-2).

questions.question: What miraculous provision did God promise through Elisha to sustain the armies in the wilderness?
options: The valley would be filled with water without wind or rain
Manna would fall from heaven
A river would flow through the desert
They would find an oasis
questions.correctAnswer: The valley would be filled with water without wind or rain
questions.explanation: Elisha prophesied water would fill the valley miraculously (2 Kings 3:16-17), demonstrating God’s sovereign provision (cf. Exodus 17:6; Isaiah 43:19; John 4:14; Revelation 22:1-2).

questions.question: What was the broader divine mandate given to the coalition regarding the cities and land of Moab?
options: To destroy cities, fell trees, stop wells, and spoil the land
To spare the cities and make peace
To only defeat Moab’s army and return
To build altars to the LORD in Moab
questions.correctAnswer: To destroy cities, fell trees, stop wells, and spoil the land
questions.explanation: Elisha instructed total devastation (2 Kings 3:19), showing God’s judgment on persistent rebellion and sin (cf. Deuteronomy 20:16-18; Joshua 6:21; Jeremiah 48:1-47).

questions.question: How did God’s intervention affect the Moabites’ perception of the battle according to 2 Kings 3?
options: They saw the water as red as blood and thought the kings were dead
They saw a great army approaching and fled
They received a message to surrender
They were blinded and confused
questions.correctAnswer: They saw the water as red as blood and thought the kings were dead
questions.explanation: The Moabites misinterpreted the reflection of water as blood (2 Kings 3:22-23), demonstrating how God can confuse enemies (cf. Exodus 14:24-25; Judges 7:19-22; 2 Chronicles 20:22).

questions.question: What was the outcome of the battle for Israel and its allies against Moab?
options: They defeated Moab, smote cities, stopped wells, and felled trees
They were defeated and retreated
They made a treaty with Moab
They lost many men but took prisoners
questions.correctAnswer: They defeated Moab, smote cities, stopped wells, and felled trees
questions.explanation: Israel and allies successfully executed Elisha’s commands, showing God’s deliverance (2 Kings 3:24-25), consistent with divine justice and victory in Scripture (cf. Joshua 11:12-15; Psalm 44:3; Romans 8:37).

questions.question: What desperate act did the king of Moab commit when the battle was too severe for him?
options: He offered his eldest son as a burnt offering on the wall
He fled to Edom for refuge
He surrendered to Israel
He prayed to Chemosh for deliverance
questions.correctAnswer: He offered his eldest son as a burnt offering on the wall
questions.explanation: The king sacrificed his heir (2 Kings 3:27), illustrating the depths of pagan desperation and idolatry, contrasting with biblical prohibitions (cf. Leviticus 18:21; Jeremiah 7:31; Hebrews 10:5-10).

questions.question: What was the reaction of Israel to the Moabite king’s burnt offering of his son?
options: There was great indignation against Israel, and they departed
They intensified their attack
They called for a ceasefire
They mourned for the boy
questions.correctAnswer: There was great indignation against Israel, and they departed
questions.explanation: The text says there was great indignation against Israel leading to their departure (2 Kings 3:27), indicating divine displeasure or fear of defilement, reflecting God's holiness and justice (cf. Ezekiel 20:26-29; 1 Corinthians 10:20-22).

questions.question: What does the narrative of 2 Kings 3 teach about God’s providential care and sovereignty over nations?
options: God orchestrates events to fulfill His purposes even through human sin and political alliances
God is indifferent to the affairs of nations
God supports only Israel regardless of their obedience
God acts only when asked explicitly to intervene
questions.correctAnswer: God orchestrates events to fulfill His purposes even through human sin and political alliances
questions.explanation: The chapter shows God’s sovereign control over kings and nations, using alliances and miracles to fulfill His will (2 Kings 3:10-20), consistent with Isaiah 45:1-7, Daniel 4:17, Romans 13:1, and Revelation 19:11-16.
